characters: THE EVIL DEAD / THE LAST TEMPTATION OF CHRIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montage is choreographed to 'Never Tear Us Apart' by INXS Donnie pedals down into the suburban village of Middlesex Virginia ...passing by a large rock 'Middlesex' rock-patt Donnie pedals past two neighbourhood women who are speedwalking with handweights. They smile at him. A Pontiac Trans-Am speeds by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie turns the corner and heads towards the garage. We pan over to the Darko house... moving through the fron yard where Eddie Darko (forty-four) pulls the cord and hi gas-powered leaf-blower roars to life. Elizabeth Darko (nineteen) comes out the front door. She approaches her dad from behind. Eddie turns and aims the leaf-blower at her face... blasting her with air

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie parks his bike and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back from Samantha Darko (ten) as she is jumping a trampoline and pan over to Rose Darko (forty-two) as sh sits at a table reading a paperback copy of Stephen King' "IT". She glances over to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks into the kitchen. He then goes to the refrigerator. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca Printed in magic marker on the refrigerator notepad is t phrase:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opening theme of "Who's the Boss?" begins as we see T Danza's blue van and the title card. We reveal Samantha, sitting on the floor, singing softly to the theme song "B New Life" performed by Larry Weiss We pan over to Donnie, sitting in the La-Z Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Darko family has convened for dinner. They eat silent for several moments.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I'm voting for Dukakis.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Perhaps when you have children of your own that need braces, and you can't afford them because half of your husband's paycheck goes to the federal government, you'll regret that decision.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (amused bitterness) I'm not gonna squeeze one out until I'm thirty.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Will you still be working at Yarn Barn? 'Cause that's a great place to raise children.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: No, a year of partying is enough. She'll be going to Harvard this fall.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I haven't been accepted yet, mother

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (smiles) If you think Michael Dukakis will provide for this country prior to the point when you decide to squeeze one out, then I think you're misinformed.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: When can I squeeze one out? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his sister) Not until like... eighth grade.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (to Donnie) Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Donnie? You're a dick.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Whoa, Elizabeth. A little hostile, there. Maybe you should be the one in therapy. Then Mom and Dad can pay someone two hundred dollars an hour to listen to all of your thoughts... so we won't have to.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Maybe you'd like to tell Mom and Dad why you stopped taking your medication. An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (surprised) You've stopped taking your medication?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: When can I squeeze one out, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (glaring at Elizabeth) You're such a fuck-ass.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: When did you stop taking your medication?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (laughing) Did you just call me a fuck-ass?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Donnie) You can suck a fuck.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, please tell me, Elizabeth, how exactly does one suck a fuck? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted) We will not have this kind of language at the dinner table. They are all silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: What's a fuck-ass? Despite his brave efforts to hold back laughter, Eddie Da lets out a slight guffaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth talks on the phone, getting ready for her Satur night. Rose knocks and then enters.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (into the phone) No. I took a year off to be with you. (beat) Of course I care. Don't get angry. (covering the phone) What?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: How did you know -

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) I didn't realise it was such a big deal.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: It is a big deal.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I caught him flushing pills down the toilet. He knows you check the container.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie lies on his bed, reading "Collected Short Stories" Graham Greene. His room is an organised wreck. Rose enters and begins to pick things up of the floor

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Get out of my room. Rose bitterly turns to leave, but stops at the door

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I wish I knew where you went at night. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Did you toilet paper the Johnson's house?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (still reading) I stopped rolling houses in the sixth grade, Mom. (beat ) Get out of my room.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You know... it would be nice to look at you some time... and see my son. I don't recognise this person today.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Then why don't you start taking the goddamn pills? Donnie leans over and turns off his lamp. Rose turns and leaves her son alone in the dark, closing the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stops in her tracks, hearing this. She then walks in her bedroom and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose goes into bed with Eddie, who is reading a hardback copy of Stephen King's "The Tommyknockers".

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Our son just called me a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (beat) You're not a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie removes his pills from the medicine cabinet. We se insert that reads: L. THURMAN M.D. He looks at the bottle for a moment, and then takes three pills and swallows them... staring at his reflection in t mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sits up in bed, unable to sleep. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV pops on. Eddie drops into the La-Z Boy. They are replaying a Bush/Dukakis debate. Eddie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back and pan over to a grandfather clock... as th hand reaches midnight. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (whisper ) Wake... up... Donnie. Donnie jerks upright in his bed, awakened from a bad drea He looks over at his alarm clock: 12:50 a.m. His expressi is distant... confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie stares at Eddie, asleep in the La-Z Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks into the kitchen, removes the magic marker f the refrigerator message board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks to the front and exits the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks down the front walk to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie arrives next to the pin and stares off into the distance. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva night for a walk... huh, Donnie? Donnie stares off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tonight is very special, Donnie.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I've been watching you. (beat) Do you believe in God, Donnie? Donnie doesn't answer. He holds his stomach, taking deep breaths.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God loves his children, Donnie. God loves you. There... standing on the seventh hole is a six-foot-tall figure dressed in a grotesque bunny suit. Donnie stares at the Bunny nervously as a wave of nausea overcomes him.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: My name is Frank. (beat) I want you to follow me.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm here to save you. (beat) The world is coming to an end, Donnie. Donnie doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look up in the sky, Donnie. He looks up into the black night.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 28 days... 6 hours... 42 minutes... 12 seconds. That is when the world will end. Donnie looks back at Frank. His expression is a vacant ex of confusion. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth comes through the front door, leans back agains it, closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie Darko sleeps reclined in the La-Z Boy. The final no of the Channel 12 National Anthem fade away to static. From above... a thunderous crash. Plaster rains from the ceiling ...Books fly off the bookshelf as the entire wall mount collapses to the floor. Eddie jerks awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth falls back in horror as plaster rains down from around the chandelier... debris falling in the dining-roo doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie is curled up, asleep on the green. A golf ball lan on the green and rolls within inches of his head. A golf cart filled with four older men arrives. Dr. Fishe (forty-five) gets out first.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FISHER
dialogues.text: Donnie Darko? (beat) Son? What's going on here? Jim Cunningham (forty), the man riding shotgun, gets out the cart and walks over.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Who is it, Don?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FISHER
dialogues.text: Eddie Darko's kid. Donnie gets up and brushes himself off. On his arm he see something written in black magic marker Numbers.... 28:06:42:12. Donnie stares at the numbers on his arm, confused.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Jim, kissing his ass) Sorry about this, Jim, just a... a kid from the neighbourhood. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to Donnie) So let's stay off the greens at night

dialogues.speaker: OK
dialogues.text: Jim Cunningham stares at Donnie with a friendly grin.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Dr. Fisher. It won't happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks down the street towards his house. A fire engine. Two police cars. A news van... All parked front of his house. There are dozens of neighbours in the street surrounding barricade. Donnie moves through the crowd where a Police Officer is standing.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Hey, I live here!

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Are you... Donnie Darko?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah! The Officer lets him through. Near the cul-de-sac there is a large caterpillar crane li something from inside the house. There are firemen roamin around. Two Police Officers are speaking with Eddie and R Donnie looks over at the house. A crane lifts a gigantic jet engine over from the house towards a large flatbed truck. Firemen kick pieces of woo and shingle from the roof. He turns and sees his entire family standing there. Eddie holding Samantha.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: It fell on your room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men in suits approach from a black sedan. A police of directs them to Rose. One of the men removes a badge from his pocket and holds it up for Rose to see. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  10.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Darko, my name is Bob Garland and this is David Coleman. We're with the FAA. If you don't mind we'd like to speak with you and your husband privately. Elizabeth looks over at Donnie with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (whispering) They don't know where it came from. Donnie looks over in awe as the mammoth engine is now str to the flatbed truck. A man in a silver firesuit sprays t engine down with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is signing some documents in front of Garland at a table that has been set up. Another FAA guy is there.

dialogues.speaker: FAA MAN
dialogues.text: (pointing to the document ) And then here as well. Eddie signs off, and Garland takes the documents.

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: We've arranged for you to stay ata hotel, get some sleep. We'll take care of things here. Eddie picks Samantha up into his arms. He stands with Ros and Elizabeth... turning towards Donnie... who seems lost a trance.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Come on, Donnie... we're going to a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: P.M.
dialogues.text: Donnie lies in bed, watching television. Elizabeth is spr out on the other bed. Samantha sits on the edge of Elizab bed, holding a stuffed unicorn named Ariel

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: If it fell from a plane, then what happened to the plane?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: They don't know, Samantha. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  11.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Is there any way that we can make money from this? Couldn't we get on television if we sue the airline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Eddie lie awake in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: So let me get this straight. No airline will claim ownership of the engine. So we have to wait for the FAA to decide who fixes my roof. (beat) Fuck that. We're taking the money out of savings.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (quoting Rod Serling) You are entering a new dimension of sight and sound... Rose begins to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Why do I have to sleep with Donnie? He stinks.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: When you fall asleep tonight, I'm gonna fart in your face.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (walking to the door) I'm telling Mom.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Samantha, don't go over there.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Frankie Feedler.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Frankie Feedler. You remember him from high school?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (long beat) He was a year ahead of us? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  12.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: He died, remember? On the way to the prom. (beat) He was doomed. Rose lies there silently.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. They could have said the same thing about Donnie. Our Donnie. (beat) But he dodged it. He dodged his bullet, Rose. Rose rolls over to embrace him.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's my boy. Moments later, the door to the adjoining room opens. It i Samantha.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Mom, Donnie said he's gonna fart in my face. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose drops Donnie and Samantha off at the corner.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Ms. Farmer will pick you up from recital. Bye, now. She pulls of in the Taurus. Already waiting at the bus stop is Joanie James (eleven) Also Cherita Chen (fifteen)

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Hi, Cherita.

dialogues.speaker: CHERITA
dialogues.text: Chut up. Also there are Donnie's two best friends, Sean Smith (six and Ronald Fisher (fifteen) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  13.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: (raising his hands in victory) DARKO CHEATS DEATH! Man... you're famous! I called you, like, a jillion times last night!

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: We went to a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: My dad said he found you on the golf course. Are you sleepwalking again?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I don't wanna talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Now that you're famous, you gotta have a smoke. Sean hands Donnie a Marlboro Red and he takes it, looking over at Samantha and Joanie.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: What happens if you tell Mom and Dad about this, Samantha?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: You'll put Ariel in the garbage disposal.

dialogues.speaker: JOANIE
dialogues.text: So... grody. Sean, Ronald and Donnie light up. Ronald is the most amat looking.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Cherita... want a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: CHERITA
dialogues.text: Chut up.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: (mimicking) Chut up!

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Go back to China, bitch!

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Leave her alone, man. Cherita looks over at Donnie... her quiet devastation poo hidden. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following montage is three long Steadicam shots in th main school hallway and courtyard. We follow Donnie and his friends as they pour out of the back of the emergency exit of the school bus to 'Head Ove Heels' by Tears for Fears. We pick up teachers Karen Pomeroy (twenty-seven) and Dr. Kenneth Monnitoff (thirty) and Kitty Farmer (forty-two), with Jim Cunningham, as they make their way through the hallways. Swarms of girls surround Donnie as he makes his way to hi locker. There is a huge smile on his face. We reveal Gretchen Ross (fifteen)... we see Principal Col (thirty-eight) and then Samantha's dance team (Sparkle Mo practising their routine in the courtyard. We follow Ms. Pomeroy into English class... then time-lap dissolve through the doorway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Pomeroy has been reading from "The Destructors" by Gr Greene.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: "There would be headlines in the papers. Even the grown-up gangs who ran the betting at the all-in wrestling and the barrow-boys would hear with respect how Old Misery's house had been destroyed. It was as though his plan had been with him all his life, pondered through the seasons, now in his fifteenth year crystallised with the pain of puberty." Donnie sits in the front.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is Graham Greene trying to communicate in this passage? Why do the children break into Old Misery's house? Joanie James raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joanie.

dialogues.speaker: JOANIE
dialogues.text: They wanted to rob him. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  15.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: Joanie, if you had actually read the short story... which, at a whopping thirteen pages must have kept you up all night, you would know that the children find a great deal of money hidden in a mattress. But they burn it. The class gives an "Awwww." Joanie blushes.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Donnie Darko, perhaps, given your recent brush with mass destruction, you can give us your opinion?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Well... they say it right when they are ripping the place to shreds. When they flood the house. That like... destruction is a form of creation. So the fact that they burn the money is... ironic. They just want to see what happens when they tear the world apart. (beat) They want to change things. Gretchen Ross stands at the doorway to the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: May we help you?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: I just registered, and I think they put me in the wrong English class. Ms. Pomeroy studies her.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: You look like you belong here.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Umm, where do I sit? Ms. Pomeroy thinks for a moment. There are several empty chairs.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: Sit next to the boy you think is the cutest. Girls, get up. The whole class begins to freak out. The girls all get ou of their seats... eating this up. Ronald fixes his hair.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Quiet! Let her choose. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  16. Without hesitation, Gretchen scans the class for every gu As she gracefully takes her seat next to Donnie, they mak eye contact. Donnie grins ear to ear The class freaks out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie drives Donnie down Old Gun Road, a windy back-road that goes towards the country.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: So how was school today?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: It was great. We had peanut-butter sandwiches and apples and honey at snacktime. And then during show-and- tell, my stuffed walrus was a big hit.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Good Lord. (beat) So the construction guys say it'll take about a week to fix the roof. Damn airline better not fuck us on the shingle match.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Do they know yet?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Know what?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Where it came from?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No... apparently they can't tell us what happened yet. Something about a matching serial number that got burned. (beat) But I had to sign a form saying I wouldn't talk to anyone about it.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: So we're not supposed to tell anybody what nobody knows?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You tell Dr. Thurman whatever you want. Suddenly, Eddie slams on the brakes and the station wagon comes to a sudden stop. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  17.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, shit!

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Grandma Death. Standing in the road directly in front of the car is Robe Sparrow (101 years old, a.k.a. Grandma Death) Grandma Death lives in a modest brick house that sits bac in a huge grassy field that overlooks the entire town. He mailbox sits on the edge of Old Gun Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie gets out of the car and takes Grandma Death's hand walking her back towards her mailbox. He opens it for her

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: No mail today. (smiles) Maybe tomorrow. Grandma Death smiles back at him... and begins to walk sl back to her house. She then turns and takes Donnie's hand into her frail grip.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA DEATH
dialogues.text: (speaking slowly) Every living creature... on this earth... (beat) ...dies alone. Donnie stands there silently for a moment, and then Grand Death turns back towards her house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a large colonial rancher in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lilian Thurman (fifty-eight) is a beautiful older wom

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Your mother said that you've been skipping cycles of your medication.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I've been taking it. I just like to make her feel guilty for all of this. You know, abuse her. Psychologically.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: All of this... certainly isn't your mother's fault, Donald. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  18. He is quiet for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: So, I met a new friend.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Would you like to talk about this friend?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: His name is Frank.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I think he saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Don't you watch the news?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: I don't own a television.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: A jet engine fell on my house.. landed on my bed. While I was talking to Frank on the golf course. Dr. Thurman looks at him for a long beat, analysing wheth or not he is telling her the truth.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not kidding. Concerned, Dr. Thurman leans in closer.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Frank... instructed you... to get out of bed... just before this happened.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: He said to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Follow him where?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Into the future. (beat) Then he said that the world was coming to an end. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  19. He rubs his arm, where the numbers are still lightly draw

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Do you believe that the world is coming to an end?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (long beat) No. (beat) That's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the empty school hallway... a gigantic tidal wave form in the distance and comes crashing towards us between the lockers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie lies on the couch... fast asleep. His eyes slowly open. There, standing in the corner of the room in the shadows Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Wake up, Donnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dark school hallway, Donnie rounds the corner with flashlight, a can of spray paint, and an axe. Frank stand in the same hallway where the tidal wave crashed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie shines the flashlight through the basement. He approaches some old piping. Donnie puts the axe back over his shoulder and then lower it fiercely. The smashing of metal against metal echoes through the huge room. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same group stands and waits for the bus. The guys smo Cherita stands alone. Samantha is reading something to Joanie. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  20.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (reading) "And then the prince was led into a world of strange and beautiful magic."

dialogues.speaker: JOANIE
dialogues.text: Wow. Donnie grabs the piece of paper from his sister

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (reading out loud) "The Last Unicorn!" By Samantha Darko

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Donnie! Give it back! He pushes her away.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're wrinkling it!

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hey, it's 7:45. The bus shoulda been here, like, twenty minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: Maybe Martha Moo finally went nuts and hijacked the bus.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (excited) You know, there's, like, this rule. We get to go home at 7:55.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: There's no rule!

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Fuck yeah there is! If the bus doesn't show up in thirty minutes, you're supposed to go straight home.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah... he's right. Because if we keep waiting, some guy in a van might pull up and try to molest us. And then our parents could sue the school board. Everyone starts to get excited... looking down the road t see if the bus is coming. Sean's watch hits 7:55. No bus. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  21.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: All right! 7:55. Everybody goes home.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: Let's go to Donnie's house. His parents are both at work. The three guys begin walking.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Come on, Sam, you can call Joanie's mom from home. The two girls follow them. Cherita stands at the corner.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Cherita... you should go home.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, if you're still here and the bus comes, we'll get in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: CHERITA
dialogues.text: Chut up.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hey, porky pig. I hope you get molested! Suddenly, Emily Bates (ten) and Susie Bates (eight) run u to the bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Hey! Our mom said that school is cancelled today because it's flooded!

dialogues.speaker: JOANIE
dialogues.text: No... way. A horrible expression appears on Donnie's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A janitor named Leroy (fifty-five) stands at the end of t hall with Principal Cole. Water rushes past their feet do the steps.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: I got twelve classrooms full of water All coming from a busted water main.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: What else? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  22.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: What else? Shit, Principal Cole you ain't gonna believe what else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand before the bronze Middlesex mongrel. Spray-pai on the concrete before it is the phrase: THEY MADE ME DO There are papers strewn everywhere. Embedded in the head the mongrel is an axe.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: Christ. Is that an axe?

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: How did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: (beat) I guess they made him do it. Leroy can't help himself. He has to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: You're fired. Principal Cole walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie, Sean, Ronald, Samantha and Joanie, Emily and Susi walk from their bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: School's closed! Everybody go home!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Nu-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Yeah-huh. A cat burglar broke him and trashed everything. Susie talks with Emily. Joanie and Samantha listen in.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Mom said that the boys' locker room looked like a swimming pool... and that they found faeces everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE
dialogues.text: What are faeces? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  23.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Baby mice.

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE
dialogues.text: Aww.

dialogues.speaker: JOANIE
dialogues.text: Oh my God, that is so grody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean looks down to another bus stop down the street.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: School's cancelled! A bunch of young kids scream out... jumping up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie approaches another corner alone. Ricky Danforth (seventeen) and Seth Devlin (eighteen) stand with Gretche

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: (smoking a cigarette) Has anyone ever told you that you're sexy?

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: I like your boobs. Gretchen looks at them with disgust. Donnie walks into the group.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: School's cancelled. They look at one another, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (to Donnie) Wanna walk me home?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Sure. They quickly begin to walk off. Seth and Ricky look off a them, furious. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  24.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Don't look so freaked.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I'm not. But you should check your backpack 'cause those guys like to steal shit.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Fuck them. Gretchen smiles at Donnie, and then turns back and gives them the middle finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen walk along the sidewalk together.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: So... you just moved here?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. My parents got divorced. My mom has a restraining order against my stepdad. (beat) He has... emotional problems.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I... have those too. (beat) What kind of problems does your dad have?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (long beat) He stabbed my mom four times in the chest. Donnie is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Wow. Did he go to jail?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: He fled. They still can't find him. (beat) My mom and I had to change our names and stuff. I thought Gretchen sounded kind of cool.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I was in jail once. (beat) I accidentally burned down this house. It was abandoned. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  25.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got held back in school again. Can't drive until I'm eighteen. (babbling) I think when I grow up I want to be a painter. Or maybe a writer or maybe both. Then I'll write a book and draw the illustrations like a comic book. You know, change things.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Donnie Darko is a cool name. Sounds like a superhero.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: What makes you think I'm not? Gretchen smiles. She looks over at her house.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: I should go. For physics. Monnitoff says I have to write an essay on the greatest invention ever to benefit mankind.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: That's easy. Antiseptics. She gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, the whole sanitation thing. Joseph Lister... 1895. Before antiseptics there was no sanitation especially in medicine.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: You mean soap?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Don't knock soap. Without it, disease would spread rapidly. If we ran out... you and I would never live to see the year 2000.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Wonder where we'll be then.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: The best thing about soap is that it's the only thing on earth that can never get dirty. No matter what crap you throw on it ...it always rubs off. And there it is again... perfect. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  26.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Until it withers away. She stares at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: It's a good thing the school was flooded today.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: We never would have had this conversation. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: You're weird.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: That was a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Will you go with me?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: No... I mean, will you GO with me? That's like... what they call it here. Going together.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (beat) Sure. She gets up and begins to walk up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: I'm going home. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Thurman sits next to Donnie. His eyes are closed. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  27.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: And when I clap my hands twice, you will wake up. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: So, tell me about your day, Donald.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I met a girl.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: What is her name?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Gretchen. We're going together now.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Do you think a lot about girls?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: How are things going at school?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I think about girls a lot.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: I asked you about school.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I think about.. Fucking a lot during school.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: What else do you think about during school?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I think... about... "Who's the Boss?"

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Who is the boss?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I just turn the volume down and think about fucking Alyssa Milano.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: What about your family, Donnie? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  28.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: No, I don't think about fucking my family. That's sick!

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Donnie... I want to hear about your friend Frank. Donnie is now undoing his belt. He is no longer paying attention. Dr. Thurman quickly claps her hands. Donnie jolts awake.. disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie sits with his eyes wide open, staring at something

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (out of shot) Aaron Armitage... Cherita Chen Donnie's face has gone white.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: Donald Darko. We reveal on the blackboard the phrase, "They made me do it", written over and over again. We reveal two Police Officers standing next to Principal Cole in the corner of the classroom. Donnie gets up and walks over to the board and writes the phrase. He then sits down again without hesitation. The Police Officer hesitates for a moment, lingering over Donnie's penmanship. He then places a '?' next to Donnie' name on the roster. Ms. Pomeroy makes eye-contact with hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back from a television: a cloud formation blows a the screen revealing a logo that reads: CUNNING VISIONS PRODUCTIONS. A series of interviews follows.. infomercial style.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA CONNIE
dialogues.text: And what I realised was that my entire life I was a victim of my own FEAR. I was FEEDING FEAR WITH FOOD... and finally... I looked in the mirror. Not just IN THE MIRROR. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  29.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I looked THROUGH the mirror. And in that image I saw my EGO REFLECTION. Donnie's health class is assembled in uniform rows in fro of a television cart. Ms. Farmer paces in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: SHANDA RIESMAN
dialogues.text: (with her arm around her geeky son) ...and for two years I thought it was NORMAL for a fifteen-year-old to wet the bed. Laughter from the students.

dialogues.speaker: SHANDA RIESMAN
dialogues.text: (choking up) We tried everything. But the solution was there... all along.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY RIESMAN
dialogues.text: (burst out emotionally) I'm not AFRAID anymore! A montage of "family" imagery follows.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: All across America... people have come together to join hands. People who believe that human life is too important... too valuable to be controlled by FEAR. A middle-aged man walks out onto a country patio. It is J Cunningham... the guy from the golf course.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Hello. My name is Jim Cunningham. And welcome to "Controlling Fear". The title CONTROLLING FEAR appears on the screen... follo by PART ONE: ATTITUDINAL BELIEFS.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Pay close attention, you could miss something. Donnie stares at the screen... at Jim Cunningham. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ruins of a brick chimney sit in the middle of a field Donnie, Sean and Ronald have lined up several empty beer bottles, cans and stuffed animals on the hearth. They take turns blasting these targets with a BB gun. Blam! A can falls over. Ronald hands the gun to Donnie. S pulls out a bottle of Raspberry Night Train and takes a s He hands the bottle to Ronald.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: What is this shit?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Raspberry. He takes a big sip... which results in a dry heave.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: Raspberry. That's good shit. Donnie aims the crosshairs on Smurfette's head. He pulls trigger. Smurfette falls over

dialogues.speaker: RONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wicked.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: No more fuckin' for her.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: Smurfette doesn't fuck.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Smurfette fucks all the other smurfs. That's why Papa Smurf made her, cause the other smurfs were getting too horny.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: Not Vanity. He's a homo. Blam! A bottle shatters.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Then she fucks 'em all while Vanity watches. And Papa Smurf films it. Ronald takes another sip of Night Train... followed by an dry heave. Blam! A bottle breaks.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: First of all... Papa Smurf didn't create Smurfette. Gargamel did. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  31.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She was sent in as Gargemel's evil spy, with the intention of destroying the smurf village. But the overwhelming Goodness of the Smurf way of Life transformed her into the Smurfette we all know and love. And as for the whole gang-bang scenario... it just couldn't happen. Smurfs are asexual. They probably don't even have reproductive organs down there under those little white pants. The only reason they exist is because of Magic spells and witchcraft... which is all a bunch of bullshit if you ask me. (beat) That's what's so illogical about the smurfs... what's the point of living if you don't have a dick? Donnie aims the gun... pulls the trigger. Blam! A bottle breaks.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: Dammit, Donnie! Why do you always gotta get all smart on us! Donnie takes the bottle of Night Train and takes a small sip. Their conversation is interrupted by the squealing of tyr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the hill, a Dodge minivan is stopped on Old Gun Road Grandma Death is once again in the middle of the street.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Grandma Death. Ms. farmer leans her head out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Excuse me! Grandma Death doesn't hear her. She wanders around in cir Furious, Ms. Farmer gets out of the car and walks over to the old woman, walking her by the shoulders back to her driveway.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please stay out of the road, Ms. Sparrow. If this happens again, I'm going to call social services. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  32. Ms. Farmer gets back behind the wheel and they drive off. Grandma Death lurks around her mailbox.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: How old is Grandma Death?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: A hundred and one, I think. Every day she does the same thing. But there's never any mail. Grandma Death approaches the mailbox.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Here we go... this could be it. She opens it... then closes it. Walks away.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: Awwww. That sucks. She approaches the box again...

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... we may still have mail... Opens it... closes it. Walks away.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: Noooo! They continue to watch her, sipping liquor into the sunse as Grandma Death repeats this act like an ancient wind-up doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie lies on the couch watching television... where the is a news story about the flooded school. Several constru workers are packing up their things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking nauseous, Donnie opens the medicine cabinet and retrieves his pills. He takes four of them. Donnie takes drink of water, closing his eyes. He puts the pills back closes the cabinet. In the mirror's reflection is Frank. Donnie jumps.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You got away with it. Don't worry. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  33. Donnie reaches his hand out towards Frank and it presses against an invisible wall, as if he were pressing his han against liquid glass.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: How can you do that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I can do anything I want... and so can you... Donnie stares closely at Frank. He then removes his hands and moves back away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign reads: EMERGENCY PTA MEETING TONIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parents and teachers convene in front of the auditorium entrance. Kitty Farmer hands out Xeroxed images of something. Eddie and Rose chit-chat with other concerned parents. Ms. Pomeroy approaches Kitty Farmer

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: What are you trying to accomplish here?

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: (indignant) There was urine and faeces flooded in my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd settles... Principal Cole takes the stage.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: In co-operation with the county police, we have begun an active investigation into the cause of the flooding... and our suspects include several of our own students. Kitty Farmer stands up in her seat near the front row.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: I want to know why this FILTH is being taught to our children. The crowd stirs. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty, I would appreciate... if you could wait...

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Mr. Cole... not only am I a TEACHER... but I am also a PARENT of a Middlesex child. Therefore, I am the ONLY person here who transcends the parent- teacher bridge.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: Kitty...

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: The bottom line... Mr. Cole... is that there is material being taught to our children that is cause for this destructive behaviour. She stands up.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have in my hand Graham Greene's "The Destructors". This short story is part of my daughter's English assignment. In this story, several children destroy an elderly man's house from inside out. They destroy his house without motive, without moral consequence. They destroy private property ...and they get away with it. Ms. Pomeroy shakes her head bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And how do they do this? They FLOOD the house... by breaking through the water main!

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: (trying to calm her) This meeting of the PTA was called to inform the parents of our ongoing investigation...

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: (enraged) I AM THE PTA! And I say that this FILTH is directly related to this vandalism. Applause from the crowd. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  35.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think this garbage should be removed. Several shouts of approval come from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie continues to converse with Frank

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Why did you make me flood the school?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We just want to guide you in the right direction.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Who is... we?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You'll know soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (desperate) Where did you come from?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (beat) Do you believe in time travel, Donnie? A moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Who are you talking to? Donnie turns to see Samantha is standing in the doorway. Frank is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heated debate among the parents is under way. Frustrate Rose stands up. Karen Pomeroy is furious.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Excuse me... but what is the real issue here? The PTA doesn't ban books from school.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: The PTA is here to acknowledge that there is pornography in our school's curriculum.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: (standing up) My GOD... woman, are you drunk? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  36.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Excuse me? You need to go back to grad school.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (to Kitty) Do you even know who Graham Greene is?

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: (to Rose) I think we've all seen "Bonanza" Ms. Pomeroy is disgusted. Rose and Eddie burst out laughi grab their coats, and leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen play a Sega race-car driving game. Do drives a souped-up red Ferrari through the Grand Canyon.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: So when you sleepwalk, can you remember afterward? Like, do you dream?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: No. I just wake up and I look around, try to figure out where I am... how I got there.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: My dad said never wake a sleepwalker... because they could drop dead. The Trans-Am crashes head on into a tree. Game Over

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: It's like this big force... that's in your brain. But sometimes it grows bigger... and it spread down into your arms and legs... and it just sends you someplace.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: So when you sleepwalk, you go somewhere familiar?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: No. Every time I wake up somewhere different. Sometimes my bike is laying there next to me. Like once when I woke up on the edge of this cliff up on Carpathian Ridge. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  37.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: And you'd never been there before? They sit silently for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Donnie?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Do you ever feel as though there's always someone watching you?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Well... maybe someone is, like... giving you these dream steroids. And sleepwalking ...is someone showing you the way. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie stands in front of the class. Ms. Pomeroy sits beh her desk. On the chalkboard is "Poetry Day".

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: "A storm is coming, Frank says. A storm that will swallow the children... and I will deliver them from the kingdom of pain." (beat) "I will deliver the children to their doorsteps. I will send the monsters back to the underground. I will send them back to a place where no one can see them ...except for me. Because I am Donnie Darko." Donnie returns to his seat. Ms. Pomeroy stares at him intensely.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: Who is Frank?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: A six-foot-tall bunny rabbit. The class begins to laugh. Donnie looks over at Gretchen. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Farmer stands next to the television where Jim Cunnin narrates the Lifeline tutorial.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: And so, let us begin Lifeline Exercise No. 1. "PLEASE PRESS STOP NOW" appears on the screen. Ms. Farmer stops the tape and moves to the blackboard. On it, she has drawn a horizontal line book-ended by the wor "Love" and "Fear".

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: As you can see, the Lifeline is controlled by two polar extremes: "Fear" and "Love". Fear is in the negative energy spectrum. Love is in the positive energy spectrum.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (to Donnie) No duh.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Excuse me? (defensive) "No duh" is a product of fear She stares them down for a moment... shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (handing out cards) Now, on each card is a CHARACTER DILEMMA which applies to the Lifeline. Please read each character dilemma aloud... and place an X on the Lifeline in the appropriate place. The students read their cards.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY FARMER
dialogues.text: We'll start in the front. Cherita Chen stands up and walks over to the blackboard. Ms. Farmer pulls up large white cards that have black-and white animated cartoons on them.

dialogues.speaker: CHERITA
dialogues.text: Juanita has an important maths test today. She has known about the test for several weeks, but has not studied. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  39.

dialogues.speaker: CHERITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In order to keep from failing her class, Juanita decides that she will cheat on the maths test. Cherita places an X near the "Fear" end of the lifeline.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Good. Next. Donnie watches as several more students interpret their respective human dilemmas. Finally... it is his turn.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Ling Ling finds a wallet on the ground filled with money. She takes the wallet to the address on the driver's license but keeps the money inside the wallet. Donnie looks at the blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Ms. Farmer, I just don't get this.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: (impatient) Just place an X in the appropriate place on the Lifeline.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I just don't get this. Everything can't be lumped into two categories. That's too simple.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: The Lifeline is divided that way.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Well, life isn't that simple. So what if Ling Ling kept the cash and returned the wallet? That has nothing to do with either fear or love.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: (impatient) Fear and love are the deepest of human emotions.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Well, yeah... OK, but you're not listening to me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  40.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are other things that need to be taken into account here. Like the whole spectrum of human emotion. You're just lumping everything into these two categories... and, like, denying everything else. Ms. Farmer stares at Donnie vehemently. She can't believe what she's hearing.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People aren't that simple.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: (not knowing how to argue with him) If you don't complete the assignment, you'll get a zero for the day. Donnie thinks for a moment... and then raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and his parents sit in front of Principal Cole.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: Donald... let me preface this by saying that your Iowa scores are... (looking down at the file) ... intimidating. (rubbing his temples) So... let's go over this again. what exactly did you say to Ms. Farmer? Donnie does not answer. We reveal Ms. Farmer standing in corner.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: (furious) He asked me to... forcibly insert the Lifeline exercise card into my anus. Silence. Rose looks down, furious. Eddie lets out a snort laugh which he tries to conceal with a cough. It doesn't work. INT. TEACHERS' LOUNGE / OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER (2:15 P.M. Eddie and Donnie exit Cole's office, moving on while Rose approaches Kitty, who looks visibly shaken.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Kitty, I don't know what to say. They've suspended him for two days. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  41.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Ever since this jet fiasco, I honestly don't know what has gotten into him.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Rose, I'll tell you this because our daughters have been on dance team together for two years and I respect you as WOMAN. But after witnessing your son's behaviour today, I have... Significant doubts... (stopping herself) Our paths through life must be righteous. I urge you to go home and look in the mirror and pray that your son does not succumb to the path of fear. Kitty Farmer turns and walks away. EXT. DARKO BACKYARD / PATIO - SUNSET (MAGIC HOUR, 5:30 P. Samantha jumps up and down on the trampoline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks into his room again for the first time since the accident, looking around at the new furniture, paint carpet. Everything is perfect. Elizabeth appears in the doorway behind him with a cordle phone in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Oh my God, remember that gym teacher Ms. Farmer? (beat) Yeah. Well, I guess my brother called her a fat bitch today in class and got suspended. And my parents just bought him all of this new shit. (beat) Yeah, I know. I wish a jet engine would have fallen on my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Rose sit across from one another at the bistro patio... having a quiet dinner to themselves.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: He's too old to be behaving this way. Eddie considers this. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  42.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I say we buy him a moped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie lies in bed... looking up at the ceiling. He then rolls over and looks at the calendar on his wall. The day of the month of October are marked off with an X in each square. Tacked onto the calendar is a drawing of Frank.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: 28 days, 6 hours, 42 minutes, 12 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As everyone is leaving class, Donnie stays behind.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Dr. Monnitoff?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: Donnie.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I know that this is gonna sound kinda weird... but do you know anything about time travel? Dr. Monnitoff pauses, turns and looks at Donnie. He seems know something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Monnitoff has drawn a diagram on the blackboard. In h hand he holds a copy of Stephen Hawking's "A Brief Histor of Time".

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: So... according to Hawking... wormholes might be able to provide a shot cut for jumping between two distant regions of space-time.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: So... in order to travel back in time, you'd have to have a big spaceship or something that can travel faster than the speed of light --

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: Theoretically.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: -- and be able to find one of these wormholes. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  43.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: A wormhole with an Einstein-Rosen bridge, which is, theoretically... a wormhole in space controlled by man.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: So... that's it?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: The basic principles of time travel are there. (beat) So you have the vessel and the portal. And the vessel can be anything. Most likely a spacecraft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cherita Chen listens to this conversation intently.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Like a DeLorean.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: (smiling) A metal craft of any kind. Donnie stares at him intently. Dr. Monnitoff walks over t his desk and picks up a book.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't tell anybody that I gave you this. (beat) The woman who wrote it... used to teach here a long time ago. She was a nun for many years and then overnight she just became this entirely different person. She up and left the Church, wrote this book and started teaching science. Donnie takes the battered book... we see the cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie stands before an array of old photographs. We zoom to a black-and-white photograph of a young Robert Sparrow standing in a class photograph dated 1944. Donnie looks down at the book, and then at the photograph

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Roberta Sparrow... Grandma Death. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie sits down for dinner with his family.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: It's called "The Philosophy of Time Travel".

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What does time travel have to do with philosophy?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Guess who wrote it? No one seems to know.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Grandma Death.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: That is a terrible nickname.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Grandma Death.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (to Eddie) You know, Roberta Sparrow. We almost hit her with the car the other day.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I've heard she's loaded. The family is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You're right. Roberta Sparrow was famous for her gem collections. Kids used to try and steal stuff from her all the time. Over the years... as she got older, she became more and more of a recluse... now she just likes to stay up there all by herself.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I guess she just lost faith in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow motion. Donnie and Gretchen jump up and down on the trampoline, lost among falling autumn leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie is back on Dr. Thurman's couch. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  45.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: How many times have you seen Frank?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Four times... so far.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Can anyone else see him?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I don't think so. It's like a TV station. And they're tuned into mine and no one else's.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Who is they? Is Frank part of some larger group?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Gretchen has a theory. That Frank is a sign. I told her I thought it was ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: A sign from whom?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) I think that Frank wants me to go to this woman. (holding up the book) She wrote a book about time travel. Frank asked me if I believed in time travel. That can't just be a random coincidence. (beat) My dad almost hit her with the car the other day, and she said the creepiest thing. She said that every living creature on this earth dies alone.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: How does that make you feel?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: It reminded me of my dog Callie.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Is Callie still around?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: No. She died when I was eight. We couldn't find her for days. She went and crawled underneath our back porch... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  46.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Do you feel alone right now? He looks at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I'd like to believe that I'm not... but I've just never seen any proof. So I just choose not to bother with it. It's, like, I could spend my whole life thinking about it... debating it in my head. Weighing the pros and cons. And in the end, I still wouldn't have any proof. So ...I don't even debate it any more. Because it's absurd. (beat) I don't want to be alone. (beat) So, does that make me, like, an atheist?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: No. That makes you keep searching. Donnie takes this in for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Dr. Fisher watch the Redskins game. Ronald and Donnie watch the game in the family room.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Ahh... we need Theisman.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FISHER
dialogues.text: We need a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Anne Fisher (forty-five) share a bottle of wine the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: And so, his tapes made me realise that for forty-five years I have been a a prisoner of fear. Rose, you have to meet Jim Cunningham. (taking a sip of wine) I can't believe he's not married. Samantha bounces through the kitchen and into the family room, wearing a Dorothy outfit from "The Wizard of 0z".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie sits back in the La-Z Boy, dozing off... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  47. John Madden's CBS chalkboard unfolds on the TV screen. Ma traces his electronic lines across the screen, tracing th movement of the players... as their images are frozen in time. Donnie's eyes close... and then re-open. Donnie turns his head and sees that the room is momentari bathed in artificial white light, as if God hit the slow- motion button during a flash of lightning. Donnie turns his head and sees that protruding from his father's stomach... is a thick spear made of silvery plas gel. As Eddie gets up from the couch to walk over to the refrigerator ...his spear precedes him... morphing into a extruded arrow that reaches the refrigerator several seco before him. The spear traces the exact geography of his movement thro time... using his centre of gravity as its axis point. Donnie turns and sees Samantha skipping from the kitchen. as her spear bounces several feet in front of her like a caterpillar. Her spear... smaller than her father's... is proportional her mass.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (her voice echoing through the silence) Follow the yellow brick road... Donnie looks down at his stomach and sees his own spear protruding outward. It then begins to extrude forward tow the foyer. He does not follow it. It then retreats back in and becko him to follow. Like a child transfixed by a firefly... Donnie follows th path of his spear into the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and his spear round the corner and arrive in his parents' bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His spear leads him to the closet. He opens the closet do and the spear leads him down to a box hidden beneath his father's shoe rack. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  48. Donnie removes the box from the closet and unlatches it. Inside is a gun. Donnie removes the pistol from the box.. staring at it with the same childlike expression. Suddenly... Donnie's universe snaps back to normal. The w light strobes... the spear has vanished. Donnie still holds the gun. His expression changes to ner shock. His eyes linger over the gun for a moment, he then quickl puts it back in the box... and carefully places the box b under the shoe rack. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual bus stop crew is there. Donnie arrives last... himself. He looks tired and preoccupied. A plane flies overhead... they all look up at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the students placing the Graham Greene books on Ms Pomeroy's desk.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: It gives me no pleasure to deny you the right to read one of the great writers of the twentieth century. But... alas, I have not yet been elected Queen of the Universe. And until that day, I will be forced to obey the rules... and so will you. So... if anyone is found carrying this book in school, they will be suspended. Donnie slips his book into his backpack

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But let's not worry. Someone has already pre-ordered several dozen copies at Sarasota Mall Waldenbooks. now, in Mr. Greene's absence, we will be reading another classic. Richard Adams' "Watership Down". She begins to hand out copies of the paperback novel. Bet Farmer smiles when she sees the cover

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Awww. Bunnies. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  49.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: (whispering in his ear) Donnie, maybe you and Frank can read this one together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks along the edge of the school. Suddenly, a fi approaches, grabbing him from behind, placing a switchbla next to his throat. It is Seth Devlin.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: Did you tell them that I flooded the school?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I didn't say shit.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: That's not what I heard. Now they think I did it.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Well, if you're innocent, then you have nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: You know what? I think that you did it. Seth takes the knife and pokes the tip softly into the fl of Donnie's neck, drawing a small amount of blood. He pushes Donnie away. Donnie touches his neck in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks into the classroom and takes his seat next t Gretchen. He is sweating profusely. Dr. Monnitoff is handing out papers. The bell rings Peopl shuffle out.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: Don't forget tomorrow we'll be meeting with our partners for the Young Inventors Fair. Donnie rubs his finger over his neck wound.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: What happened to your neck?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  50.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) So what happened to your neck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen walk around the trail.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Were you ever afraid of the dark? They pull over to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Why? She thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Babies cry because they're afraid of the dark. And because they have no memories... for all they know... every night could be the last forever Like, perpetual darkness.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Why not just buy your baby a night light?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: That's not good enough. You've got to go back in time and take all those hours of darkness and pain and replace them... with whatever you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: With, like, images?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Like... a Hawaiian sunset... the Grand Canyon. Things that remind you how beautiful the world can be. Donnie stops and takes Gretchen's hand.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: You know... we've been going together for a week and a half...

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: And what?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: You want to kiss me... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  51. Donnie goes in for an awkward kiss... but Gretchen turns denies him. Donnie turns away, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: That's alright... I understand.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) No... Donnie, wait. I've never...

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I always wanted it to be at a time when ...when it reminds you how beautiful the world can be.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. And right now there's some fat guy over there watching us. A man in a red jogging suit is standing there in the fore smoking a cigarette. He turns away... disappearing into t woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie rides along the sidewalk... and skids to a stop, s a wallet lying there. Donnie opens the wallet, looking at the ID. It reads:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (echoing in Donnie's head) Now you know where he lives. Donnie looks over and sees that he is in front of Cunning Tudor mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie sits at the kitchen island with Elizabeth, carving pumpkin.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So I hear you have a girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What's her name? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  52.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: You're not gonna tell Mom, are you?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (defensive) Why would I tell Mom?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Because you tell Mom everything.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No I don't. (long beat) She worries about you.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Well, don't worry... I'm taking my medication.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It's not that. I mean mouthing off to your teachers. I'll admit... when Dad told me what you said to Ms. Farmer, I laughed my ass off.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I was just being honest.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yeah... well, that's not the way the world works. If you keep being too honest, the world will eventually find a way to destroy you.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Her name is Gretchen.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That's a nice name. (beat) OK, let me see it. Donnie turns the carved jack o' lantern around and we see that it looks remarkably like Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Eddie sit in front of Dr. Thurman.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Thank you for seeing us... We... just felt that it was time to discuss...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: What I think is going on with your son. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  53.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Well, you know about his past. And when you said to look for signs of aggression ...He was recently suspended from school for insulting his gym teacher.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: She deserved it.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Rose... let me just lay out what I believe is happening here. Donnie's aggressive behaviour seems to stem from his increased detachment from reality. His inability to cope with the forces in the world that he perceives to be threatening. Rose smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Has your son ever told you about Frank?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Frank... the giant bunny rabbit?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Frank?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Donnie is experiencing what is commonly called a daylight hallucination.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You're telling me my son has an imaginary friend?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: He has described lengthy conversations... physical encounters with what I believe to be a manifestation of his subconscious mind. Rose looks over at Eddie with an expression of panic.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I... What can we do? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  54.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: I would like to put him through more hypnotherapy... and increase his medication. Eddie looks at Rose... who nods in approval.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: If that's what you think is necessary.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: But let me remind you that this treatment is... experimental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks into the kitchen and removes a butcher's kni from a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie stands in front of the bathroom mirror... catatoni looking at his reflection. Frank stands behind him. Suddenly, Donnie turns around with the butcher's knife an lunges at Frank with all of his weight. The knife collides with Frank's invisible force field as it were liquid steel. Donnie lunges repeatedly at Frank w psychotic rage... but the knife bounces off. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The auditorium is packed with Middlesex mongrels. Jim Cunningham takes the stage.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: (shouting) Good morning, mongrels!

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: (scattered voices) Good morning...

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: That's all the gusta you can musta? I said, "Good morning!"

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: (yelling louder) Good MORNING! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  55.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Now that's better... but I still sense some students out there... who are AFRAID ...just to say GOOD

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
