dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Are you AFRAID?

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: (screaming louder)

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Now that's what I like to hear (suddenly serious) Because too many young men and women today are paralysed by their fears. They give in to their feelings of self-doubt... they surrender their bodies to the temptations of drugs, alcohol and premarital sex. Empty solutions. These are toxic chemicals ...and disease-spreading behaviour. A large screen lowers behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would like to tell you a story today about a young man whose life was destroyed by the instruments of fear. A young man searching for love... in all the wrong places. (shaking his head tragically) His name was Frank. On the giant screen, an image slide appears of a young ca teenager whose eyes are whacked out on drugs. The title appears: HIS NAME WAS FRANK. Upon hearing the name Frank, Donnie falls into a paranoid trance. Gretchen, who looks extremely bored, leans over to Donnie

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here. Donnie ignores her. His eyes are locked on Jim Cunningham who begins his rousing re-enactment of the sad, unfortuna downfall of Frank. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  56. Within minutes, Jim Cunningham has the crowd laughing... enamoured of him with his cartoon slide show. Note: during this sequence, the camera speed ramps to 4 b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie is in a trance.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: We're moving through time.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: What? The huge screen rises upwards and Jim Cunningham takes questions from the crowd from portable mike stands in the back of the auditorium. Several students get up and go to the mikes.

dialogues.speaker: DORKY GIRL
dialogues.text: Hi. Um... my stepsister... like... I sometimes worry that she eats too much.

dialogues.speaker: OVERWEIGHT GIRL
dialogues.text: (mortified; yelling at her sister from the crowd) Shut up, Kim!

dialogues.speaker: DORKY GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to help you!

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: There's no need to be embarrassed. Many times we eat because we are afraid to face the reality of our ego reflections. We shouldn't just look INTO the mirror. We should look THROUGH the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: DORKY GIRL
dialogues.text: Thanks. Kitty Farmer runs out onto the stage and hands Jim Cunnin a bottle of water and a towel. She gives him the thumbs-u sign, and runs back offstage.

dialogues.speaker: LANKY KID
dialogues.text: Um... How can I decide what I want to be when I grow up? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  57.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: I think you should look deep within yourself... deep within your heart... and find what it is in the world that makes you feel LOVE. Just pure LOVE. And then go to that. In your studies... in your athletics... go towards love.

dialogues.speaker: LANKY KID
dialogues.text: Thank you. Donnie gets up from his seat and goes to the mike.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY RIESMAN
dialogues.text: What can I do to learn how to fight?

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Violence is a product of fear. Those who love themselves enough should have no need to fight another person. Learn to truly love yourself... and the world will be yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Donnie steps up to the mike stand.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (furious) How much are they paying you to be here?

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Excuse me? What's your name, son?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Gerald.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Well, Gerald, I think you're afraid.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Well, Jim, I think you're full of shit! There are rumblings from the faculty. Some laughter from student body.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you telling us this crap because you want us to buy your book? Because I'll tell you something, that was some of the worst advice I've ever heard! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  58.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Dorky Girl) If you want your sister to lose weight... tell her to get off the couch, stop eating Twinkies... and maybe go out for field hockey. (to Lanky Kid) You're never gonna know what you want to be when you grow up. Most of the time, nobody does. How about you, Jim? (to Larry) And you... Sick of some jerk shoving your head in a toilet? Then go lift some weights... take a karate lesson. And when he tries to do it again... kick him in the balls. More rumblings from the faculty... Laughter from the stud gets louder.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: (getting angry) I think you are afraid to ask me for advice. I think that you are a very troubled... confused young man. I think you're searching for answers in all the wrong places.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (long beat) Well, I think you're the fucking Anti-Christ. The crowd is stirring. Students break out into applause. Principal Cole approaches Donnie and removes him from the auditorium. Gretchen watches him go with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen walk down the wooded road.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (mumbling) They suspended me for two days.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (stopping) Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (long beat) I've been seeing stuff... a lot of really messed-up stuff. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  59.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Do you know who Grandma Death is?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: The old crazy woman who lives off Old Gun Road. Donnie takes out the book by Roberta Sparrow.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. (taking the book) "The Philosophy of Time Travel". What is this?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: She wrote it. (beat) There are chapters in this book that describe the stuff I've been seeing. It can't just be a coincidence. (beat) Will you come see her with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen stand at the end of Grandma Death's driveway. Gretchen leads Donnie up to the front porch of the decrep house. She then rings the doorbell. They wait for several moments ...nothing happens. Gretchen then goes and peers through a window.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I know she's here. She never leaves the house.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Maybe she's asleep. They walk to the end of the driveway, and Donnie stops at the mailbox. He opens it... empty.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing at the house) Donnie, look. In an upstairs window of the house, the silhouette of Gra Death peers down at them ominously. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie sits at his desk, sealing an envelope. The address reads:

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLESEX, VA 23113
dialogues.text: Title card:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Thurman looks at a diagram from Sparrow's boo. Donnie pacing around her office.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: And they grow out of our stomachs?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: It was just like she described them in her book. Like they were alive. The way that they looked... moved... smelled. They were like workers... assigned to each one of us. (long beat, then distant) I followed my spear... and I found something...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: What did you find? Donnie is silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Have you told Gretchen about the spears?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but if I told her about the other stuff about Frank...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Are you embarrassed by these things that you see?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: You know... every week I come in here and I tell you stuff... and it's all embarrassing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  61.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tell you stuff that I don't tell anyone else... and you know what? It's your turn, Dr. Thurman. I'm not saying anything else until you tell me something embarrassing about yourself. Donnie makes a "zipper lip" gesture.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: (long, stubborn beat) I once had an extended sexual fantasy involving Mr. Rogers. Donnie just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Whoa. (beat) That's OK, Dr. Thurman, it's nothing to be embarrassed about. I have sexual fantasies all the time too.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I mean... Gretchen... She won't even let me kiss her. She says because it's our first kiss... she's, like, waiting for this big... moment or something. I just don't get it. I just want to get it over with so we can move on to the good stuff.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: The good stuff.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah... you know... (whispering) Fucking.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Have you ever made love, Donald? Donnie looks at her... and we know the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire family is having dinner. Donnie is lost ina trance. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  62.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Donnie, are you coming to my talent show tomorrow? Donnie ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: He can't, Samantha. He's been suspended from after-school activities. Donnie... are you still with us? (beat) How was your therapy session tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Fine. You know, Dr. Thurman isn't so bad a lady. I can tell her anything. Rose appears surprised and then sad at this comment. She looks at Eddie, who just looks down at his plate of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen are at the front of the room, present their invention. Dr. Monnitoff presides.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: So, we call them... IMGs

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Infant Memory Generators.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. So the idea is that... you buy these glasses for your infant, and they wear them at night when they sleep.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: And inside these glasses are these slide photographs. And each photograph is of something peaceful... or beautiful. Whatever pictures the parent wants to put inside.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: What effect do you think this would have on an infant?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Well... the thing is, nobody remembers their infancy. And anyone who says they do is lying. We think that this would help develop memory earlier in life. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  63.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: Did you stop and think that maybe infants need darkness? That darkness is part of their natural development. Seth Davis raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: What if the parents, like... put in photographs of Satan... pentagrams, dead people... stuff like that?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Is that what you'd show your kids?

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: I mean, didn't your dad, like, stab your mom? Dr. Monnitoff looks over at Seth calmly.

dialogues.speaker: SETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get out. Seth begins to walk out. Gretchen doesn't answer. There i only the 80 IQ grin... staring back at her face. The room silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gretchen walks out the front door. Donnie comes chasing a her.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Gretchen! Gretchen... wait up! She turns and faces him, tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. They embrace... kissing for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old-fashioned theater marquee reads:

dialogues.speaker: THE EVIL DEAD / THE LAST TEMPTATION OF CHRIST
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen approach the box office.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Two for "Evil Dead", please. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen sit in the middle of the huge, empty theater. "The Evil Dead" unfolds. They eat popcorn and watch silen Donnie looks over and sees that Gretchen is asleep. Donnie turns back to the movie... beginning to look ill.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Feeling sick? Donnie turns his head over and looks across Gretchen. Fra is sitting next to her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: You have to do something for me first.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You have a request?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Tell me why you're wearing that stupid bunny suit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Why are you wearing that stupid man suit?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Take it off. I want to see you. After a moment, Frank slowly reaches up and removes the r headpiece. Donnie's eyes widen. Underneath the headpiece is the human face of a handsome young man. His left eye does not exist, because it has imploded into the socket. There is blood oozing from the wound.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Satisfied? Donnie just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: What happened to your eye?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I am so sorry. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  65.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Why do they call you Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It is the name of my father... and his father before me.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: How much longer is this gonna last?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You should already know that. (beat) Watch the movie, Donnie. I have something to show you. Donnie looks at the screen. On the screen, "The Evil Dead" morphs into a Time Portal.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's a storm coming. (beat) Have you ever seen a Portal, Donnie? Suddenly... the screen morphs into an image of a large Tu house.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Burn it to the ground. Donnie pulls out Jim Cunningham's wallet from his pocket. Donnie contemplates his fate for several more moments, an then gets up and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks slowly past the theatre marquee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the stage, among blowing autumn leaves, Cherita Chen performs a strangely beautiful mime act to Symphony No. 3 Henryk Gorecki. When her act is finally over, the crowd is indifferent, w scattered applause and laughter. Ms. Pomeroy stands up an applauds enthusiastically. Clearly affected by the laughter, Cherita walks offstage. In the front row, the entire Darko family has assembled. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty Farmer stands with the five-member dance team ina huddle.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Now girls... I want you to concentrate. Failure is not an option. And Bethany... if you feel the need to vomit up there. Just swallow it.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: OK, Mom. Jim Cunningham walks past them towards the stage. He stop and touches Samantha on the shoulder... smiling.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Good luck out there. She smiles nervously back at him. He exits onto the stage

dialogues.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Thank you... Cherita Chen. That was Autumn Angel. (clearing throat) Next... it is my distinct pleasure to introduce to you... Emily Bates... Suzy Bailey... Samantha Darko... Beth Farmer ...and Joanie James. They are... SPARKLE MOTION! The audience roars with applause as the lights dim. The following montage alternates between the auditorium s and Jim Cunningham's house. The stage lights slowly raise as the opening beat of 'Wes End Girls' by the Pet Shop Boys begins. Under the soft stage lights... Sparkle Motion unfolds. Donnie approaches Jim Cunningham's house. Sparkle Motion... in perfect synchronicity. In the living room of the house... Donnie walks through, dousing gasoline all over the place with psychotic force. trail of fire spreads. A mystery woman emerges from the back wall of the auditor A couch and curtains become engulfed in flames. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  67. Middlesex girls are jumping up and down in the aisles. Eddie and Rose are smiling ear to ear Elizabeth Darko is cracking up at the entire scene. Kids are going bonkers in the aisles. The mystery woman takes off her glasses. Slow motion: fire engulfs a deer taxidermy. Ms. Pomeroy gets into the groove. The parents are now on their feet. The crowd roars even louder Slow motion: Sparkle Motion stands triumphant. Slow motion: Donnie stands before a wall of flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cherita sits alone in the courtyard at the base of the mo statue... defeated and alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks into the theatre and sits next to Gretchen, is asleep. As the credits to the film roll, Donnie wakes her.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (disoriented) What? How long was I asleep?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: The whole movie. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firemen walk through the charred room shining flashlight. A Fireman shines his flashlight onto a mysterious door wi smoke emerging from it. He kicks the door in... and shines the flashlight into th dark hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen lie awake on a pile of blankets... st out into the abyssal canyon. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  68. Helicopter shot: we swoop down over Carpathian Ridge... p Donnie and Gretchen... of evergreen forest. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: OCTOBER 22 1988
dialogues.text: over the canyon and the endless expanse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Eddie are in the backyard raking leaves onto a giant sheet.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I know everyone thinks I'm a nutcase. I've been getting a lot of weird looks from people lately. They rake in silence for a moment. (angry)

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Who's been giving you weird looks?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: A lot of people. Teachers. Younger kids. It's like they're afraid of me for some reason. (beat) But that's OK... because I know I deserve it. Eddie stops raking.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You're my only son... I know, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I know I'm not the best... communicator. (beat) But whatever happens in your life... whatever obstacles you come up against... you just say... and do whatever is in your heart. You be honest... and tell the truth... even if they look at you funny... and they will. They'll tell you that you're wrong. They'll call you a fool. (beat) But what you've got to understand, son, is that almost all of those (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  69.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: people are full of bullshit... and they're scared of people like you. Because you're smarter than all of them. Donnie smiles at his father

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie sits on his bed and stares at the calendar on his wall. Each day is marked with an xX. He takes his pills from his nightstand... and downs three There are noises coming from downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie comes downstairs to see Elizabeth glued to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh my God, that's him. That's the guy from last night. On the television: a Newscaster stands in front of the ch heap of what was once a large suburban house. Firefighter mill about behind her.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: As firefighters continue their investigation, arson has not been ruled out as a cause of the fire particularly because of the shocking discovery made earlier today among the burned ruins. In the basement of the house, authorities have discovered what has been described as a kiddie- porn dungeon. Policemen emerge from the basement with several large box of evidence.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cunningham, who has become a recent celebrity for his motivational books, audio tapes and videos, ducked his head from cameras when he was arrested at the Sarasota Heights Golf Club this morning. In a vicious statement Cunning Visions executive Linda Connie attacked the Middlesex Fire Department... claiming a vast conspiracy. Donnie stares at the television... speechless, horrified. the TV, Jim Cunningham hides his face from the camera. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  70.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Dad played golf with that guy. Donnie says nothing, turns around... and walks upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Dr. Monnitoff are having another in-depth conversation.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: Each vessel travels along a vector path through space-time... along its centre of gravity.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Like a spear.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: Beg pardon?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Like a spear that comes out of your stomach?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: Uhh... sure. And in order for the vessel to travel through time it must find the portal, in this case the wormhole, or some unforeseen portal that lies undiscovered.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Could these wormholes appear in nature?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: That... is highly unlikely. You're talking about an act of God.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: If God controls time... then all time is pre-decided. Then every living thing travels along a set path.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: I'm not following you.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: If you could see your path or channel growing out of your stomach, you could see into the future. And that's a form of time travel, right? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  71.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: You are contradicting yourself, Donnie. If we could see our destines manifest themselves visually... then we would be given the choice to betray our chosen destinies. The very fact that this choice exists... would mean that all pre-formed destiny would end.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Not if you chose to stay within God's channel...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Donnie, I'm afraid I can't continue this conversation. I could lose my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Pomeroy sits across from Dr. Monnitoff. They both gra papers silently. Dr. Monnitoff stares at her for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Donnie... Darko. She stares at him for a while, haunted by something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Pomeroy sits across from Principal Cole.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Karen, this is a specialised school. We don't think the methods you've undertaken here are appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: "Appropriate". (trying to contain her anger) With all due respect, sir, what specifically about my methods do you find inappropriate? Principal Cole stares at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: I don't have to get myself into a debate about this, Karen, I believe I have made myself clear. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  72.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: You call this... clarity? I don't think you have a clue what it's really like to communicate with these kids. You don't think that they can smell your bullshit from a mile away? Every day that goes by ...that we fail to... inspire them... is another moment that we all lose. And we are losing them to apathy, and this... prescribed nonsense. They are slipping away...

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: I am sorry that you have failed. Now if you'll excuse me, I have another appointment. You can finish out the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Pomeroy steps out from Principal Cole's office. She s Kitty Farmer and the Sparkle Motion girls milling about. mystery woman is there as well. Ms. Pomeroy glares at Kitty Farmer before leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Pomeroy steps outside through an emergency exit. She stares out at the beautiful forest. Her eyes are filled w tears.

dialogues.speaker: FUUUUUUUCKKKKKK
dialogues.text: Hearing the scream from the distance, we see Cherita Chen turn her head in shock as she walks alone along the edge the school building, eating her lunch. She and Ms. Pomeroy share a moment of eye contact before turns and heads back into the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Pomeroy walks slowly through the hallway, wiping tear from her face.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL COLE
dialogues.text: (over the intercom) Good afternoon. It is my great pleasure to announce that the Middlesex Middle School dance team has been invited to perform on Ed McMahon's Star Search '88 in Los Angeles, California... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sparkle Motion girls squeal with excitement... jumpin up and down. Kitty Farmer pumps her fist in victory. Suddenly... Linda Connie bursts into the office, grabbing Kitty by the arm. The teacher holds up a newspaper... whe there is a headline that reads: JIM CUNNINGHAM CHARGED. Kitty's facial expression goes from elation to horror

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The classroom is dark. The students watch "Watership Down the movie. Donnie is asleep. Gretchen stares at him. Ms. Pomeroy sta at Gretchen. Suddenly, she turns on the lights, turning off the TV. Donnie wakes up... with dark circles under his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: And when the other rabbits hear of Fiver's vision, do they believe him? (cough) It could be the death of an entire way of life, the end of an era.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Why should we care?

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: Because the rabbits are us, Donnie.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Why should I mourn for a rabbit like it was a human?

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: Is the death of one species less tragic than another?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Of course. A rabbit is not like us. It has no history books... it has no knowledge of sorrow or regret. I like bunnies and all. They're cute... and they're horny. And if you're cute and horny... then you're probably happy that you don't know who you are... or why you're even alive. But the only thing I've known rabbits to do is have sex as many times as possible before they die. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over at Gretchen, who looks angry at this.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's no point in crying for a dead rabbit... who never feared death to begin with. The class is silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: You're wrong. (beat) You're wrong about these rabbits. These rabbits can talk. They are the product of the authors imagination. And he cares for them. So we care for them too. We care that their home has been destroyed... and that their lives are in danger. Otherwise ...we've missed the point.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: But aren't we forgetting the miracle of storytelling? The dea ex machina. The god machine. That is how the rabbits are saved. Gretchen looks across the room at Donnie with a disdainfu expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie approaches Gretchen at her locker.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: You want to skip fourth period and go to the Ridge?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (angry) What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? She turns and walks off, leaving Donnie broken and deject

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie sits at his desk looking at an intricate drawing o cloud formation. On it he has written: THE PORTAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Eddie are in the kitchen. He is getting ready fo business trip. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  75. Samantha is jumping up and down. Elizabeth is jumping up down, dancing with her. Donnie looks into the kitchen from the foyer, catching hi family in a serene, contented moment of happiness. A mome that he chooses not to interrupt. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doorbell rings. Rose answers the door Kitty Farmer is there on the front porch. She is wearing shirt that reads: GOD IS AWESOME!

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Rose.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Kitty...

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Rose, we have a crisis. (beat) I am sure that you are aware of the horrible allegations against Jim Cunningham.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes, I saw the news. Something about a kiddie-porn dungeon.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: (holding up her hand) Please! Don't say those words. (shaking her head) Well... as you can see... many of us are devastated by this news. This is obviously some kind of conspiracy meant to destroy an innocent man. And I have taken it upon myself to spearhead the Jim Cunningham defence campaign. But unfortunately my civic duties have created a conflict of interest... which involves you.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Beg pardon?

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Rose... I have to appear at his arraignment tomorrow morning. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  76.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And as you know, the girls also leave for Los Angeles tomorrow morning. Now, as their coach... I was the obvious choice to chaperone them on the trip.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: But now you can't go.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Yes. And believe me, of all the other mothers I would never dream of asking you, given the predicament with your son. But none of the other mothers are able to go.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Oh, Kitty, I don't know. This is so last-minute... Eddie is in New York...

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARMER
dialogues.text: Rose... I don't know if you realise how great an opportunity this is for our daughters. This has been a dream of ours for a long time. (beat) Sometimes I doubt your commitment to Sparkle Motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is standing in Donnie's room alone. She stares at a drawing of Frank that he has tacked onto his bulletin boa Donnie appears in the doorway. Rose jumps.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I feel like... I'm approaching something horrible. Donnie walks over and sits on his bed. Rose goes and sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I have to take the girls to Los Angeles tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Do you get to meet Ed?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: If I'm lucky. (beat) So... I won't be back until the first. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  77.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your dad will be back on Sunday, so I've put Elizabeth in charge until then. She has the car... so she can drive you to your therapy tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: How does it feel to have a wacko for a son?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (embracing him) It feels wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose brings her luggage out to the airport van. Mystery W loads Beth Farmer into the van. Donnie sits on the back-porch steps, watching everyone silently. Elizabeth gives Samantha a hug.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're gonna win. I know it.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: So do I. (to Donnie) Bye, Donnie. Donnie waves goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Here are the keys to the Taurus. There's plenty of groceries in the fridge. And I left money on the kitchen table. And don't forget...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Mom. Just go, you'll miss your flight. Rose turns... wanting to say goodbye to Donnie, but not knowing how. She smiles and waves goodbye. Donnie waves back. Rose turns and goes to the van... handing the driver her last bag.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Mom... Donnie stands up and reluctantly approaches from the porc

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's nothing broken... in my brain. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  78. Rose stands there for a moment, looking at her only son.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Come on, Mom!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (to Donnie, holding back tears) I know. She gets into the van, as Donnie and Elizabeth watch them drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks up to Gretchen, who stands at her locker wit several other girls. The girls whisper to each other as h approaches.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Will you please talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Not now, Donnie. It isn't a good time.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Then when? I have to talk to you. Gretchen walks away, looking back at him with apologetic eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks alone through the hallways... lost. He stumbles upon Ms. Pomeroy's room. She sits behind her desk... which has been packed up into a cardboard box.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (knocking on the door) Ms. Pomeroy... what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: Donnie... it's Friday. Shouldn't you be off with your friends, scaring old people?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: I don't know. That's a good question... but suffice to say that I am no longer your English teacher They fired me. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  79.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: That's bullshit. You're a good teacher.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Donnie. And you're a good student. Lazy... but a good student. Unlike most of the others, you question Mom and Dad's rules.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: What do I tell the rest of the class when they ask about you?

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: (long beat) Tell them that everything is going to be just fine. (beat) It is up to the children to save themselves these days. Because the parents ...they don't have a clue. Donnie looks at the blackboard. On it she has written in perfect penmanship: "Cellar Door".

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: What's "Cellar Door"?

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: (spaced out) A famous linguist once said... that of all the phrases in the English language, of all the endless combinations of words in all of history... that "Cellar Door" is the most beautiful. She is silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Cellar door.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: Sometimes it's the only thing that keeps us going. She takes the box and crosses the room towards Donnie.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... will Donnie find his Cellar Door?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I think I already have. (beat) But now she won't even talk to me. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  80.

dialogues.speaker: MS. POMEROY
dialogues.text: Then go find her, Donnie. Don't let her get away. (stopping at the door) She was right about the rabbits. Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that... Ms. Pomeroy turns and walks down the hal with her career in a cardboard box... heading towards the bright Friday afternoon sunlight. Donnie walks back down the hallway... lost in his own introspection. Across the way... at her locker... as Cherita Chen. Donni approaches her slowly like a cat. She turns from her locker... and they make eye contact. She looks at him warily, frightened. A book falls from he arms onto the floor. Written in large letters on the brown book cover is his n DONNIE DARKO. He comes face to face with her, grabs her earmuffs with b hands, and touches his forehead to hers as if he were goi to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (long beat) I promise that one day things will get better for you. Cherita holds still for a moment, trembling, and then jer back from him. Her earmuffs come off in his hands. She backs away from him slowly. A single tear rolls down cheek.

dialogues.speaker: CHERITA
dialogues.text: Chut... up! She then turns and runs down the hall... disappearing fro sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks by himself... thinking... wearing Cherita's earmuffs. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: OCTOBER 29 1988
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie is under hypnosis.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: And when I clap my hands together twice, you will wake up. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: So, your parents... why did you disappoint them?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I... I was playing with fire.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Is it Frank who wants you to destroy the world, to set the world on fire? Donnie doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: People get hurt.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: But it was an accident. The house was under construction.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: People get hurt. I don't want to hurt anyone.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: But you were punished.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yes. I went to jail.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Do you wish that you were punished by your parents instead?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: They... didn't buy me what I wanted for Christmas that year.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: What did you want for Christmas that year?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Hungry Hungry Hippos. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  82.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: How did you feel... being denied those Hungry Hungry Hippos?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Regret.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: What else makes you feel regret?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: That I did it again.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: (alarmed) You've done it again?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yes. I flooded my school... and I burned down that pervert's house. I think I only have a few days left... before they catch me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Why did you do these things, Donnie? Did Frank tell you to commit these crimes? He does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I have to obey him... because he saved my life. He controls me and I have to obey him or I'll be left all alone... and I'll never figure out what all of this means...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: If God exists?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I think now that he might...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Because I'm so horny.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: God exists because you're horny.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I think so. I think that's one of the clues. It's a clue that tells us... to keep going. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  83.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Where are we going? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are we going, Donald?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I have the power to build a time machine.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: How is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Grandma Death will teach me how. Soon.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Then how is time travel possible?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: It would have to be God's portal. They will lead me to it. Then I will go back in time... and I won't feel regret anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: When will this happen?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Soon. Time is almost up. Donnie gets up on his feet, staggering around the room. H looks frightened... childlike.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It has to happen soon, it has to happen soon. Dr. Thurman gets up and tries to control Donnie... follow him around the room.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: What is going to happen?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (freaking out) Frank is going to kill.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Who is he going to kill? Dr. Thurman grabs him, trying to get him under control in awkward embrace. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  84.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is he going to kill? Donnie stares across the office like a frightened child.. as the room becomes white with artificial light. Frank is there in the office... staring back at him.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (freaking out) I can see him right now!

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Where is he, Donald?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: He's right there... He can read my mind and he'll show me the way out of this. The sky is going to open up... and then He will reveal himself to me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: If the sky were to suddenly open up... there would be no law... there would be no rule. There would only be you and your memories... the choices you've made and the people you've touched. The life that has been carved out from your subconscious is the only evidence by which you will be judged... by which you must judge yourself. Because when this world ends, there will only be you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and him... and no one else.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: It's too late. I've already ruined my life.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: You will survive this... Donald. I promise you that you will survive. You must let me help you. (beat) And when I clap my hands together you will wake up. She claps her hands together twice... and Donnie snaps ou of his trance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie, calmed down and putting his jacket on, walks slow to the doorway. Dr. Thurman stands looking out the window. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  85.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Donald? Donnie turns back and faces her. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your medication. They're placebos. Just pills made out of water.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Donald, an atheist is someone who denies altogether the existence of a God. You are an agnostic. An agnostic is someone who believes that there can be no proof of the existence of God... but does not deny the possibility that God exists.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Dr. Thurman.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THURMAN
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Donald.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks into the kitchen, where Elizabeth is sitting the table.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (in shock) I got in. I'm going to Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Donnie sits down across from her.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom and Dad won't be back until Sunday night. It's Halloween Carnival. We should throw a party. We could totally get away with it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (long beat) Okay, but it has to be a small one.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Everything is going to be just fine. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neighbourhood kids are trick-or-treating. The man in the jogging suit shines a flashlight towards the house. There are at least two dozen cars parked in front... and somebody is already throwing toilet paper in the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings. Donnie answers the door... only to fi Sean and Ronald dressed in black with monster masks. They are both carrying backpacks. Donnie is dressed in a black skeleton suit, and his face painted white like a skull.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: We got eggs, water balloons, and a dozen rolls of toilet paper

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: I stole four beers from my dad.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: There's a keg here.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Only pussies drink keg beer. They go back into the house towards the kitchen. There ar at least forty people, already quite wasted, many carryin their own twelve-packs of beer under their arms. Almost everyone is wearing a costume. Donnie and his frie weave through the crowd toward the patio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and his friends watching the party unfold. The party grows larger

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Thurman paces around her office with the phone to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone is ringing. The answering machine picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings... and once again Donnie is the one to answer it. To his surprise... it is Gretchen standing on front porch. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  87.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (very upset) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Hey. You OK?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (walking inside) My mom is gone.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (close to tears) I don't know. She didn't leave a note. The house is all messed up.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: But you're OK? She nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you call the cops?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, they told me to get out of the house. Donnie takes Gretchen into the hallway and gives her a hu

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm so scared... I just keep thinking that something awful has happened. It's my fucking stepdad. I know it.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (embraces her) It's safe here. Donnie takes Gretchen upstairs. We reveal Elizabeth watch them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks over to a friend.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (yelling over the music) Have you seen Frank? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  88.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: No. I think they said they were going on a beer run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen sit on the bed. Gretchen takes a sip beer.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Some people are just born with tragedy in their blood. He kisses her. He then pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: There's something you have to know, Gretchen. (beat) Everything is going to be just fine. They lie down together... silently listening to the party below. The phone is ringing. The answering machine picks up.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (on the answering machine) If you're there, please pick up. (beat) Oh well... there's good news. The girls... they got three and a half stars... and they get to come back for the quarter-finals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stands at a payphone while the Sparkle Motion girls wait at the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Semi-finals, Mom!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Sorry... semi-finals. Anyway... we're taking the red-eye back tonight and we should arrive around six a.m. I hope everything is alright. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move towards the grandfather clock and see the minute hand reach midnight. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen walk downstairs. They kiss, and she g towards the family room. Donnie walks towards the kitchen, but then doubles over against the wall in pain. Suddenly... the room blows out with a strobe of white lig as costumed teenagers and their vector spears intersect i shimmering maze of chaos. Donnie slowly follows his spear as it leads him through t crowd... directly towards the refrigerator Donnie stares blankly at what he sees... scrawled in magi marker on the memo board. It reads: FRANK WAS HERE... WENT TO GET BEER! Donnie stares at the board for several moment... he then turns his head and sees a teenager with a Ronald Reagan m walk by. He then sees another spear come towards him. Gretchen rou the corner, coming in from the family room. Donnie falls to his knees and puts his face inside the en of Gretchen's spear. We see his P.O.V. - an abyssal tunne of light.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Where are we going? He grabs her and pulls her out the back of the kitchen in the back yard. Ronald and Sean follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move through the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Donnie, what's going on! She stops him.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Time is running out. We have to go see Grandma Death. We have to talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Why? Is this about the book? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  90.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: No. Frank.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Who's Frank? Ronald and Sean approach.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Donnie? Where are we going? Donnie looks at Gretchen... This is it.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: She knows. I know she knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group of hour ride their bikes down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride their bikes through the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand in front of the dark house. It is pitch-black. lights anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: There's nobody here... Just forget it. Then... there is a clanking noise from somewhere around t side of the house. Everyone hears it. Donnie looks towards the lower front of the house where t is a cellar door.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Is that a cellar door?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (his eyes widen) Yeah... The cellar door is ajar... and there is a dim light comin out from inside.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: Don't open it, Donnie. Let's just leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie and Gretchen open the door to the cellar... and de down into a murky pit with a stone floor. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  91. Inside... the room is quite large... filled with row afte row of boxes, paintings, antique furniture and chandelier There is even an ancient piano in the back. Gretchen slowly reaches her hand out and places her finge on the deepest piano key. Suddenly a figure emerges from the shadows and slams Donn into the wall. He then grabs Gretchen by placing an arm around her neck with a butcher's knife. It is Ricky Danforth. Seth comes out from another corner. also brandishing a butcher's knife. Both have pantyhose p over their heads.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out! Now! Ricky drags Gretchen out. Seth drags Donnie out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four of them come bursting out of the cellar Seth holds Donnie's arms down with his knees and places t butcher's knife against his throat. Ricky throws Gretchen down hard onto the shoulder of Old Road. She lets out a gasp of pain as her head hits the gravel.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Motherfuckers!

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: I have... a bigger knife now. Sean and Ronald watch... dumbfounded, backing away. Seth just stares down at Donnie with his dead eyes... pus the knife down harder, cutting off Donnie's air supply.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hey... there's someone coming! Look there's a car coming! Seth slowly turns his head and sees... far down Old Gun Road... approaching headlights.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (barely audible whisper ) Dea ex machina...

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: What did you say? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  92.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Our saviour... The headlights are getting close.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: They called the fuckin' cops! Gretchen struggles to breathe on the shoulder of the road the wind knocked out of her, semi-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: That's no cop... The headlights are getting close.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (in a hoarse whisper) Donnie... Even closer...

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: You better run.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Forget it... let's go! Seth doesn't move... He just stares down at Donnie.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: You're dead, Donnie Darko Seth gets up and runs off with Ricky into the forest... j as the approaching car crests the top of Old Gun Road at breakneck speed. Suddenly, in the bright glow of the car's headlights... i the silhouette of Grandma Death... standing in the middle the road. In her right hand she is clutching a letter Donnie's letter.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Donnie... The car swerves left, barely missing Grandma Death. The Pontiac tries to brake hard... but the wheels lock... and it goes skidding onto the shoulder. Gretchen raises her head from the gravel... into bright headlight beams. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  93. The Trans-Am goes barrelling over her like a speed-bump.. and her limp body rolls off into the grassy ditch. The Trans-Am skids off into the grass and collides head-o with the crumbling stone chimney... which explodes into t crumpled hood of the car... as it eventually comes to a s in a fury of smoke. Donnie staggers to his feet... regaining his breath. He r over to Gretchen and kneels down next to her

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Gretchen... wake up. Wake up. Her neck is broken. She has no pulse. The passenger door to the Trans-Am opens, and a passenger a clown costume gets out. The driver's side door opens and the driver gets out. He is wearing a rabbit suit. A Halloween costume. He is holding the grotesque rabbit helmet in his hand. It is Frank.

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGER
dialogues.text: Frank... what'd you do... what'd you do! Frank approaches Donnie... who raises his head from Gretc to see him for the first time... face to face... with an expression of shocked horror.

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's dead. You killed her, Frank Frank is in shock.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She's dead. Donnie slowly nods his head. Sean and Ronald approach him slowly. Grandma Death looms behind them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the fuck. Look at my fucking car!

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGER
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here. Let's get out of here, Frank!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What were you stupid fucks doing in the middle of the road? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  94.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Waiting for you. Donnie raises the gun from his father's closet with his r hand, and to his own surprise, he pulls the trigger Frank's left eye implodes as the bullet passes through hi head. His body falls limply to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGER
dialogues.text: Holy shit... The Passenger turns and runs off into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: What'd you do, Donnie? What'd you do!

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (very calm) Go home. Go home and tell your parents that everything is going to be just fine. After contemplation of the recent events... Sean and Rona turn and run off in the opposite direction. Donnie is left alone... with the dead bodies. He turns and stares at Grandma Death... who is calmly sta there... with his letter in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA DEATH
dialogues.text: A storm is coming. (beat) You must hurry. Donnie is still in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie carries Gretchen home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie looks down at Elizabeth asleep on the couch. He th leans down and gives her a kiss on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks out to the Taurus, then stops and looks up a the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Time Portal begins to form above the house. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  95. Donnie touches his stomach... feeling sick once again. Donnie then steps into the car, where Gretchen sits in th passenger seat. He turns on the engine and peels out of t driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie drives the Taurus up Carpathian Ridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie sits on the roof of the Taurus looking out. He smiles, lighting a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: 28 days, 6 hours, 42 minutes, 12 seconds. We're almost home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Time Portal in the distance, forming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha Darko is fast asleep. Her head rests on Rose's shoulder. She looks out of the window at the rising sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Portal continues to form above the Darko house. Police cars pull up in front of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie continues to stare out at the canyon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Time Portal once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie steps off the hood and gets into the car. He takes Gretchen's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the plane, Rose looks out of the window as the jet win explodes (audio only... we don't see it). She screams out the cabin shakes violently. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Time Portal continues to form over the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The left jet engine from Flight 2806 falls downward throu the sky. Beneath it, the Portal forms itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The falling jet engine approaches the hexagonal plate of light which accelerates downwards... forming a tunnel wit walls made of swirling liquid marble. The jet engine passes into the hexagonal plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a series of inter-velometer time-lapse shots... the en suburban landscape retreats backward in a fury of speed. Shot 1: a time-lapse of the mongrel statue. Shot 2: a time-lapse of the main school hallway. Shot 3: a time-lapse of the main school building. Shot 4: a time-lapse of neighbourhood street/Darko house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We Steadicam up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move towards Donnie's empty bed. Title card:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Thurman wakes up. Jim Cunningham wakes up... sobbing. Kitty Farmer wakes up... coming to a horrible realisation Karen Pomeroy and Dr. Monnitoff wake up together Cherita Chen wakes up. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jet engine falls silently through the night down towa the Darko house... having travelled back in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie wakes up. He is laughing hysterically. The engine crashes through his ceiling... engulfing the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie jumps up from the La-Z Boy... startled awake by the impact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose sits up in bed, hearing the crash.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth leans against the wall, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mammoth jet engine has plummeted all the way down thr the house, creating a cavernous hole that splits Donnie's room in half. The smoke from the wreckage begins to clear Above the engine is Donnie... impaled through the stomach a wooden beam that was once part of the floor beneath his bed. There is blood gushing from his mouth, as his face i contorted into an expression that could almost be a smile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same disaster scene as before... only more media, mor neighbours, and a Coroner. People stand around in shock.. disbelief. From the other end of the street, a girl comes riding alo on a bike... slowly taking in the entire scene. She pulls up to the kerb where a kid named David (eleven) is standi around. It is Gretchen Ross.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Hi... what's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Horrible accident. My neighbour... he got killed. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  98.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He got smooshed. By a jet engine. She stares at the house, where paramedics wheel a body ou of the front door.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Donnie. Donnie Darko They stare at the front yard for a while. We see Elizabet We see Eddie, carrying Samantha... who is crying.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I feel bad for his family.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (long beat) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did you know him? She stares at the family for several moments... and then shakes her head slowly as if trying to locate a memory th is slipping away.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: No. Rose, leaning against a tree while smoking a cigarette, notices them. She seems to recognise Gretchen... from somewhere in the vast reservoir of her memory. She waves at her. She waves back. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: THE END
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
